newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Gibson to seek acquisitions - CEO.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Gibson to seek acquisitions - CEO.

text.p: Cincinnati-based Gibson Greetings Inc's new chief executive officer Frank O'Connell said Thursday the greeting card firm has $98 million in cash and is ready to romance acquisition targets -- the first time in years the beleaguered company has been able to do so.

As reported, Gibson sent a Valentine to shareholders, posting fourth quarter earnings of $0.39 a share. That beat First Call's $0.29 consensus analysts' estimate and topped the year-ago $0.29 a share (which excludes a unit sold in 1995).

"I think first what we're looking for is probably a decent-sized acquisition that really gives us some critical mass and acceleration on a path (beyond greeting cards only)," he said in a telephone interview.
Cincinnati-based Gibson suffered 1994 derivatives losses, lost several key customers and sold an unprofitable unit. It fired its previous top executive a year ago.
With less than 10 percent of the U.S. greeting card market, it is a distant third to Hallmark Cards Inc, estimated to have more than 40 percent, and American Greetings Corp, with about one-third.
O'Connell declined to specify acquisition targets but said they might, like Gibson's candle business, be in areas that "create a romantic environment" and complement greeting cards.
Or they might be firms that can provide entree to retail outlets such as bookstores, music stores and video stores.

Gibson's licensed lines such as "Space Jams" and "Batman and Robin" are a great video tie-in, he said, adding such outlets would provide alternatives to the highly competitive mass merchandiser/supermarket/drug store arena.

O'Connell, who arrived at Gibson in August, said he plans to reach new target audiences including teens and children with "alternative" greeting cards and puzzles and toys such as model kits of Batman's car, the Batmobile.

O'Connell's strategy is for "an entertainment company in the relationship business," he said. He sees greeting cards as a medium to enhance relationships and to connect people beyond traditional greeting cards' reach -- for example, grandparents to grandchildren whose parents divorce, he said.
He plans to also grow the greeting card business with new lines such as recently launched "Ripple Effects" textured cards with what he termed "bold graphics and crisp verse."
O'Connell formerly headed trading card manufacturer SkyBox International, now part of Marvel Entertainment Group.

Analyst Eric Bosshard, with Midwest Research/Maxus Group, said that since Gibson spurned a $290 million bid from rival American Greetings last year due to antitrust concerns, he sees "a sense of urgency to generate some earnings growth."
New products, new licensing agreements and acquisitions will key top-line revenue growth, Bosshard said, adding he expects "a couple" of acquisitions this year.
The fourth quarter benefitted from a currency gain, Bosshard said, but earnings were still ahead of his expectations and reflected progress on expenses.

Gibson also topped analysts' expectations for the year, reporting $1.34 a share versus First Call's consensus $1.22 and 1995's $1.00. Sales for the year were $390.2 million versus 1995's $388.9 million.
The stock rose 1-1/16 to 20-9/16 on Nasdaq.
